title: Parse failure resilience - CCV never crashes
description:
CCV must continue processing even when individual message parsing fails. Currently:

**Current behavior (runner.go:170-173):**
```go
msg, err := ParseMessage(line)
if err != nil {
    r.errors <- fmt.Errorf("line %d: failed to parse message: %w", lineNum, err)
    continue  // GOOD: continues to next line
}
```

**Resilience requirements:**

### 1. ParseMessage() must never panic
- [ ] Add test for malformed JSON (missing braces, quotes)
- [ ] Add test for deeply nested JSON (stack overflow protection)
- [ ] Add test for extremely long lines (1MB+)
- [ ] Add test for invalid Unicode

### 2. OutputProcessor must handle all message types safely

- [ ] Handle missing expected fields gracefully
- [ ] Handle unknown message types without crashing

### 4. Channel safety
- [ ] Handle closed channels gracefully
- [ ] Handle context cancellation during processing
- [ ] Ensure no goroutine leaks

### 5. Recovery patterns
- [ ] Add recover() in parseStdout() to catch any panics
- [ ] Add recover() in processMessage() for safety
- [ ] Log recovered panics to stderr

**Testing approach:**
- Fuzz testing with random malformed input
- Chaos testing with concurrent access
- Fault injection for all error paths

- All error paths are tested

title: Enhanced terminal output formatting with colors, spacing, and improved visual hierarchy
description:
## Overview
Add rich terminal formatting to CCV output to make it visually appealing and easier to read, similar to how Claude Code displays its output.

## Visual Requirements

### Colors
- **Green**: File names, paths, success messages
- **Yellow/Gold**: Command names, flags, variable names
- **Cyan**: Environment variables, inline code references
- **White/Default**: Regular text content
- **Dim/Gray**: Line numbers, secondary info
- **Magenta**: Function names, method references
- **Red**: Errors, warnings

### Bullet Points and Icons
- Use filled bullet (●) for main output sections
- Use (L) or similar for line indicators in file changes
- Use (+) for additions, (-) for removals in diffs

### Spacing and Layout
- Proper indentation for nested content (2-4 spaces)
- Blank lines between major sections
- Code blocks should be clearly delineated
- Line numbers aligned and dimmed

### Code Block Formatting
- Show file name as header (e.g., `Update(ralph-zai.sh)`)
- Display line numbers on the left
- Syntax highlighting for common patterns:
  - Strings in quotes
  - Environment variables
  - Commands/binaries
  - Flags and options
- Show added lines with + prefix and green color
- Show context lines without prefix

### Structural Elements
- Tool calls: Arrow icon with colored tool name and status
- Thinking blocks: Distinct styling with prefix
- Agent context: Badges showing agent type and status
- Section separators when needed

## Technical Implementation

### Dependencies
Consider using:
- `github.com/fatih/color` - Simple color output
- `github.com/charmbracelet/lipgloss` - More advanced styling
- Or built-in ANSI escape codes for zero dependencies

### New Files/Components
- `colors.go` - Color definitions and theme
- `format.go` - Formatting utilities
- Update `output.go` - Apply formatting to output

### Configuration
- Respect `NO_COLOR` environment variable
- Auto-detect terminal color support
- Add `--no-color` flag option

### Test Considerations
- Test with different terminal emulators
- Test piping output (should strip colors)
- Test with NO_COLOR=1

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Assistant text displays with proper formatting
- [ ] Tool calls show with icons and colors
- [ ] Code blocks display with line numbers and syntax hints
- [ ] File paths highlighted in green
- [ ] Commands/variables highlighted appropriately
- [ ] Proper spacing between sections
- [ ] Colors disabled when piping or NO_COLOR set
